Award.AwardTitle: Building a Pipeline of Cyber Warriors Through Education and Competition Offered Through Community Colleges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Brookdale Community College (BCC) is designing, implementing, and evaluating an innovative pathway from cyber talent to cyber workforce. It includes a unique public-private partnership that leverages the agility of community colleges and the course material of the SANS Institute to develop a scalable, competition-driven, hands-on education model that has a potential to help with the nation's critical shortage of cybersecurity workforce. The project designs metrics to identify individuals with the appropriate aptitude and expose them to vital, in-depth, hands-on learning model focusing on defending computer systems and networks. The project utilizes a multiphase competition-based model and, at each stage, students compete to demonstrate their competence and to advance to the next phase of the program. Students who successfully complete all components of the program and demonstrate their mastery have the opportunity to apply for residency positions where they can hone their skills working with practicing security professionals on real-world projects. The proposed competition and residency based model for developing the cybersecurity technical talent has a real potential for dissemination and implementation in a large number of the 1,200 community colleges nationwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Building a Pipeline of Cyber Warriors Through Education and Competition Offered Through Community Colleges” created the CyberAces Academy at Brookdale Community College. In years one and two of the grant, nearly 1,000 individuals from throughout the state of New Jersey competed in a multi-week online competition to identify individuals with untapped cybersecurity talent. Each of those years, the top 75-100 participated in a day-long SANS NetWars competition to identify the best of the best – the so-called “Top Guns”. 

The top 25 were interviewed and 11 were selected to spend a year completing five rigorous, industry-leading SANS courses and the associated certifications – two basic cybersecurity courses and three courses in one of three specialty tracks: Secure Configuration, Penetration Testing, or Advanced Forensics. PI Qaissaunee completed the five courses and certifications for Secure Configuration with cohort one. The twenty-two (22) participants selected included two women, three high school students, two high school teachers, four college students and a 54-year old Navy Veteran. 

Of the 22 cohort members, 20 completed the program with one terminated for poor performance and another withdrawing after completing one course/certification. In addition to the SANS courses, each cohort met monthly at Brookdale Community College’s Lincroft, NJ campus to perform hands-on labs and activities. These sessions, led by Qaissaunee and co-PI Ed Skoudis, although not included in the original project plan were added to encourage team-building and to develop hands-on and leadership skills. The Saturday lab days were among the highest-rated feature of the project with cohort members ultimately developing and leading activities themselves. 

CyberAces Academy graduates have secured positions at a number of firms, including IBM, CBS Networks, KPMG, Intel, Rapid7, IT services companies and a variety of DoD contractors. High school student participants have continued their studies at Temple University, Princeton University, NYU Tandon School of Engineering and Stevens Institute of Technology. The cohort building of the project has been particularly successful as has the ethos of giving back promoted and demonstrated by Qaissaunee and Skoudis. Program graduates continue to share with each other, colleagues, students and kids.

Recent efforts have focused on building the pipeline of students into cybersecurity and increasing their foundational knowledge. To that end, we have partnered with SANS on building out training exercises at pivotproject.org, using existing cyberaces.org content in our own foundational courses and promoting the adoption of SANS cyberstart “game”. Direct outreach to the K-12 community has also occurred through a partnership with two Red Bank Regional HS teachers (both CyberAces Academy graduates) and faculty in our Computer Science department. The fruit of this relationship has been successful NSA/NSF-funded GenCyber camps for high school students from under-represented minorities (URMs) (Summer 2016, 2017 and 2018).

From what was learned in this project, we have worked to strengthen our own community college offerings. The 18-credit Cybersecurity Certificate of Achievement has grown in popularity, with 29 graduates in the May 2018 commencement. Additionally, a new Cybersecurity track has been added to our existing Networking program and will go live in Fall 2018. Within our courses, we have explored a variety of lab offerings to ensure that we provide our students with the most impactful hands-on experiences. These have included labs performed on our own physical infrastructure, as well as access to labs maintained by the National Center for Systems Security and Information Assurance (CSSIA) center, Jones and Bartlett Learning, Infosec Learning and TestOut. As each platform evolves, we continue to evaluate each on a semester-by-semester basis to continually provide our students the best-in-class lab experience. 

The reach of the project has been both local and national. We have been able to provide support to colleagues at other colleges, including Clark State Community College (Dayton, OH), Borough of Manhattan Community College (NY, NY), multiple Massachusetts community colleges and a number of colleagues from conference interactions and contacts derived from project press coverage. At the college, the Criminal Justice department has adopted our Introduction to Security course as an elective in the Criminal Justice program and as a required course in the Homeland Security program. The Computer Science department has begun to adopt secure coding practices and has provided one student in each of the last two years to pursue a BS in Cybersecurity at Stevens Institute of Technology through the Scholarship for Service (SFS) program. 

Lastly, a parallel National Science Foundation (NSF) Advanced Technological Education (ATE) grant (DUE# 1601612), with Qaissaunee as PI, is focused on building freely-available interactive content and has developed foundational and advanced content in Networking and Cybersecurity (currently hosted at https://mirrorlearning.org/emate2/web/emate2.html). This ongoing work leverages external expertise from faculty at Bunker Hill Community College and will soon integrate interactive content conceived by the CSSIA center.


Last Modified: 07/30/2018
Modified by: Michael Qaissaunee
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: "Building a Pipeline of Cyber Warriors Through Education and Competition Offered Through Community Colleges" created the CyberAces Academy at Brookdale Community College. In years one and two of the grant, nearly 1,000 individuals from throughout the state of New Jersey competed in a multi-week online competition to identify individuals with untapped cybersecurity talent. Each of those years, the top 75-100 participated in a day-long SANS NetWars competition to identify the best of the best – the so-called "Top Guns". The top 25 were interviewed and 11 were selected to spend a year completing five rigorous, industry-leading SANS courses and the associated certifications – two basic cybersecurity courses and three courses in one of three specialty tracks: Secure Configuration, Penetration Testing, or Advanced Forensics. PI Qaissaunee completed the five courses and certifications for Secure Configuration with cohort one. The twenty-two (22) participants selected included two women, three high school students, two high school teachers, four college students and a 54-year old Navy Veteran. Of the 22 cohort members, 20 completed the program with one terminated for poor performance and another withdrawing after completing one course/certification. In addition to the SANS courses, each cohort met monthly at Brookdale Community College?s Lincroft, NJ campus to perform hands-on labs and activities. These sessions, led by Qaissaunee and co-PI Ed Skoudis, although not included in the original project plan were added to encourage team-building and to develop hands-on and leadership skills. The Saturday lab days were among the highest-rated feature of the project with cohort members ultimately developing and leading activities themselves. CyberAces Academy graduates have secured positions at a number of firms, including IBM, CBS Networks, KPMG, Intel, Rapid7, IT services companies and a variety of DoD contractors. High school student participants have continued their studies at Temple University, Princeton University, NYU Tandon School of Engineering and Stevens Institute of Technology. The cohort building of the project has been particularly successful as has the ethos of giving back promoted and demonstrated by Qaissaunee and Skoudis. Program graduates continue to share with each other, colleagues, students and kids. Recent efforts have focused on building the pipeline of students into cybersecurity and increasing their foundational knowledge. To that end, we have partnered with SANS on building out training exercises at pivotproject.org, using existing cyberaces.org content in our own foundational courses and promoting the adoption of SANS cyberstart "game". Direct outreach to the K-12 community has also occurred through a partnership with two Red Bank Regional HS teachers (both CyberAces Academy graduates) and faculty in our Computer Science department. The fruit of this relationship has been successful NSA/NSF-funded GenCyber camps for high school students from under-represented minorities (URMs) (Summer 2016, 2017 and 2018). From what was learned in this project, we have worked to strengthen our own community college offerings. The 18-credit Cybersecurity Certificate of Achievement has grown in popularity, with 29 graduates in the May 2018 commencement. Additionally, a new Cybersecurity track has been added to our existing Networking program and will go live in Fall 2018. Within our courses, we have explored a variety of lab offerings to ensure that we provide our students with the most impactful hands-on experiences. These have included labs performed on our own physical infrastructure, as well as access to labs maintained by the National Center for Systems Security and Information Assurance (CSSIA) center, Jones and Bartlett Learning, Infosec Learning and TestOut. As each platform evolves, we continue to evaluate each on a semester-by-semester basis to continually provide our students the best-in-class lab experience. The reach of the project has been both local and national. We have been able to provide support to colleagues at other colleges, including Clark State Community College (Dayton, OH), Borough of Manhattan Community College (NY, NY), multiple Massachusetts community colleges and a number of colleagues from conference interactions and contacts derived from project press coverage. At the college, the Criminal Justice department has adopted our Introduction to Security course as an elective in the Criminal Justice program and as a required course in the Homeland Security program. The Computer Science department has begun to adopt secure coding practices and has provided one student in each of the last two years to pursue a BS in Cybersecurity at Stevens Institute of Technology through the Scholarship for Service (SFS) program. Lastly, a parallel National Science Foundation (NSF) Advanced Technological Education (ATE) grant (DUE# 1601612), with Qaissaunee as PI, is focused on building freely-available interactive content and has developed foundational and advanced content in Networking and Cybersecurity (currently hosted at https://mirrorlearning.org/emate2/web/emate2.html). This ongoing work leverages external expertise from faculty at Bunker Hill Community College and will soon integrate interactive content conceived by the CSSIA center.
